Award.AwardTitle: FRG: Collaborative Research: Statistical Modeling and Inference of Vast Matrices for Complex Problems
Award.AbstractNarration:
Technological advances make it possible to collect and store large data with relatively low costs. As a result, scientific studies in a wide range of fields routinely generate a massive amount of data. Oftentimes, our ability to obtain measurements outpaces our ability to derive useful information from them. These pressing challenges serve as the ultimate motivation for the proposed research. In particular, this collaborative proposal presents novel research plans on the development of statistical theory and methodologies as well as computational techniques for a host of problems involving large matrices ranging from covariance matrices, volatility matrices, density matrices to relational matrices.

The past few years have witnessed an explosion of data as a result of scientific and technological advances. As data storage cost continues to fall, the focal point on these big data has been transitioning inevitably from data management towards deriving actionable insights from them. There is a pressing need to respond to these challenges and understand the profound impact of large data on scientific research and knowledge discovery. The proposed research project deals with emerging problems that arise naturally at the frontier of a multitude of scientific and technological fields such as systems biology, high-frequency finance, and quantum computing among others. As a consequence, the proposed research effort will not only push forward the state-of-the-art of statistical understanding of large matrices, but also facilitate the advancement of various scientific fields and their embracement of the digital revolution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have witnessed an explosion of data as a result of scientific and technological advances. As data storage cost continues to fall, the focal point on these big data has been transitioning inevitably from data management towards deriving actionable insights from them. There is a pressing need to respond to these challenges and understand the profound impact of large data on scientific research and knowledge discovery. The research projects deal with emerging problems that arise naturally at the frontier of a multitude of scientific and technological fields such as systems biology, high-frequency finance, and quantum computing among others. As a consequence, our research effort will not only push forward the state-of-the-art of statistical understanding of large matrices, but also facilitate the advancement of various scientific fields and their embracement of the digital revolution.

We have developed innovative statistical approaches to address the challenges encountered in handling complex statistical and computational problems with big data. In financial practices and research studies, we often involve a large number of assets and huge low-frequency and high frequency financial data. We have developed statistical techniques to integrate discrete-time models and continuous-time models for combined low and high frequency data and estimate the volatility matrices from the data. For research studies on quantum information science, we have synthesized matrix completion and quantum tomography to develop efficient large density matrix estimation techniques for studying quantum systems; we have investigated quantum annealing and created statistical methods for analyzing classical annealing and quantum annealing. These novel methodology and theory have potential applications and great implications in quantum computation and quantum information.

Our research has advanced statistical analysis of complex big data problems and thus made an important impact in the broad scientific community. The research has engaged in actitvities to integrate research with education training of graduated and undergraduate students and to attract minority and female students into statistics and other scientific fields. The research findings have disseminated broadly through prosentatons at seminars, workshops and conferences, publication at progessional journals and websites, and software distribution. They have direct applications in the fields of biomedical sciences, finance, and quantum information science.
